results.headline: Less Than Visible, but Not to Each Other
results.summary_short: Two women, decades apart in age but bonded by their relative invisibility, connect in Sean Baker’s “Starlet.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Starlet

results.headline: Coming of Age at a Critical Time
results.summary_short: The South African film “Otelo Burning” is a coming-of-age story set against the backdrop of politics and surfing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Otelo Burning

results.headline: A President Engaged in a Great Civil War
results.summary_short: “Lincoln,” starring Daniel Day-Lewis, is more a political thriller than a biopic, a civics lesson that is energetically staged and alive with moral energy, placing slavery at the center of the story.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lincoln

results.headline: Documenting the Melt, and We Are the Cause
results.summary_short: “Chasing Ice” documents the work of James Balog, who aims to illustrate the effects of global warming.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chasing Ice

results.headline: A Firehouse Fights to Save Lives, and Itself
results.summary_short: The documentary “Burn: One Year on the Front Lines of the Battle to Save Detroit” uses one firehouse to illustrate the troubles of an entire department.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Burn

results.headline: A Guatemalan Hero Fights a Corrupt State
results.summary_short: “The Return of Lencho,” directed by Mario Rosales, explores contemporary problems in Guatemala.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Return Of Lencho

results.headline: Into the Wild, Whether They Want to or Not
results.summary_short: Patton Oswalt stars in the comedy “Nature Calls,” about a camping trip gone haywire.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Nature Calls

results.headline: Jokes, Served Up Over a Meal
results.summary_short: The documentary “Lunch,” directed by Donna Kanter, looks at a group of comedy veterans including Sid Caesar, Carl Reiner and Gary Owens who gather together over the years.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lunch

results.headline: Monty Python’s Life of Graham
results.summary_short: Most of the remaining Monty Python members voice-over an animated version of Graham Chapman’s memoir, “A Liar’s Autobiography.” Chapman himself, though dead since 1989 is heard, too.
results.display_title: A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Liar's Autobiography - The Untrue Story of Monty Python's Graham Chapman

results.headline: In Search of a Common Language
results.summary_short: The three vignettes that make up “In Another Country” have Isabelle Huppert’s character dealing with various situations as the only foreigner in an overcast South Korean beach town.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Another Country

results.headline: A Cunning Tale Retold in Another Language
results.summary_short: The latest “Dangerous Liaisons” film iteration is a Chinese-language version that retains the story of pretty people behaving badly.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Dangerous Liaisons

results.headline: Tarnished New Beginnings
results.summary_short: In Lisa Albright’s turgid family drama, Bernadette Peters plays a faded Broadway diva with two daughters who starts life over in a rented, graffiti-scarred shack in Nashua, N.H.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Coming Up Roses

results.headline: When Society Stumbles, Demons Pounce
results.summary_short: “Citadel,” directed by Ciaran Foy, follows a young widower who battles demons both actual and figurative.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Citadel

results.headline: Passion Beyond Reason
results.summary_short: Jean-Marc Vallée’s “Café de Flore” follows two stories, one in contemporary Montreal and the other in Paris decades earlier.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Café de Flore

results.headline: Counseling the King, Seducing the Queen
results.summary_short: A dramatic account, directed by Nikolaj Arcel, of the affair between the 18th-century physician Johann Friedrich Struensee and the Danish queen Caroline Mathilda.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Royal Affair

results.headline: What a Man! What a Suit!
results.summary_short: Daniel Craig returns as James Bond in “Skyfall,” a playful 007 movie with exotic locales, an island fortress and a fight on a moving train.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Skyfall

results.headline: Bad-Guy Avatar Seeks Midlife Career Change
results.summary_short: Video games and cartoons meet in the new Disney feature “Wreck-It Ralph.”

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Wreck-It Ralph

results.headline: The ’80s Are Long Over, Yet the Makeup Remains
results.summary_short: Paolo Sorrentino’s “This Must Be the Place” finds Sean Penn as a washed-up rock singer who goes on a hunt for a former death-camp guard.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of This Must Be the Place

results.headline: Life Takes Nose Dive, and Settles Into an Abyss
results.summary_short: “Flight” is a story of survival that hits many familiar recovery beats, partly because transformation is the only way out when a star plays an addict in an American mainstream movie.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Flight

results.headline: The Strings Play On; The Bonds Tear Apart
results.summary_short: “A Late Quartet” follows the upheavals that threaten a fictional elite string quartet in New York as its members quarrel, cheat, get even and jockey for power.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of A Late Quartet
